qas.question: What factors would effect playing time of a phonograph?

answers.text: turntable speed and the groove spacing

qas.question: What was the playing time common in the early 20th century?
How many recordings did Kind Oliver's Creole Jazz band require?
What was the normal size disc for popular music?
What was the recording time available on a 12 inch disc?

context: The playing time of a phonograph record depended on the <a0_0>turntable speed and the groove spacing<a0_0/>. At the beginning of the 20th century, the early discs played for <a1_0>two minutes<a1_0/>, the same as early cylinder records. The 12-inch disc, introduced by Victor in 1903, increased the playing time to <a4_0>three and a half minutes<a4_0/>. Because a <a3_0>10-inch<a3_0/> 78 rpm record could hold about three minutes of sound per side and the 10-inch size was the standard size for popular music, almost all popular recordings were limited to around three minutes in length. For example, when King Oliver's Creole Jazz Band, including Louis Armstrong on his first recordings, recorded <a2_0>13<a2_0/> sides at Gennett Records in Richmond, Indiana, in 1923, one side was 2:09 and four sides were 2:52–2:59.
